prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral setup is based on our knowledge from the G28.34-P1 observations, with the considerations: 1) to prioritize the continuum sensitivity but should observe the essential lines for core dynamics and outflows. 2) to ensure a fine spectral resolution for core dynamics. Based on G28.34-P1 we choose 0.16 km/s which is sufficient to resolve the linewidth. 3) to cover outflow lines with a decent spectral resolution (1.5 km/s). We choose the coverage of the continuum spw to cover as many outflow lines as possible, after the essential ones have been covered. To reduce data rate, we averaged the channels to have a final resolution of 1.5 km/s which is sufficient for outflow studies.

The requested 0.6'' beam corresponds to 0.01-0.017 pc (2000-3500AU). The resolution is needed to resolve the local Jeans length in the very dense environment, and to resolve the individual star-forming cores in the crowded vicinity of massive cores (Wang et al. 2014; Zhang et al. 2015). It has been proven to be sufficient and adequate in our study of G28.34-P1.
The largest angular scale of the source (20'') is based on the ATLASGAL images which have a resolution of 19''. We request the ACA+TP because: 1) Although the dust emission is not resolved in the ATLASGAL images, molecular outflows are expected to be extended. 2) The dust continuum emission from many distributed low-mass cores is expected to be relatively smooth. 3) We need to measure linewidth at various spatial scale for dynamic analysis (see section 3).

We request 1-sigma rms of 0.075 mJy in a 0.6'' beam. The sensitivity corresponds to 0.05-0.08 Msun at the source distances (Zhang et al. 2015). The identification of cores is limited by confusion rather than sensitivity, hence the detection limit is often several times the rms (6-sigma in the case of G28.34-P1, see Fig 1). The requested sensitivity assure us to identify 0.5 Msun cores with 6-sigma significance, similar to what we did in G28.34-P1.
For spectral line, OT gives 8.1 mJy rms over 1/3 of the input 1.3 km/s linewidth. The corresponding rms in spectral lines is ~13 mJy per 0.16 km/s for the dense core dynamics (C18O, N2D+, etc), and ~4mJy per 1.5 km/s for the outflow lines (CO, SiO, etc). In G28.34-P1 the typical intensity for the dense core lines is 50 mJy, while for the outflow lines it is 120 mJy. Therefore, the S/N will be ~12 for the core dynamics lines, and ~9 for the outflows, assuming that the line intensities are similar in these sources. A low S/N or non-detection would be exciting, because it means the source is extremely young - exactly what we are hunting for.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The formation of massive stars is a "family affair" - they are born in a cluster together with many low- and intermediate-mass stars. The low-mass population of protostars bears critical information on the initial mass distribution of a forming protocluster. Our recent ALMA observations of a dense IRDC clump resolved 38 individual cores (0.5-16 Msun) within a 0.8 pc diameter, revealing a top-heavy core mass function (CMF) and a significant deficit of low-mass (1-2 Msun) cores. We propose to extend the study to a well selected sample of 12 intrinsically cold clumps - to maximize the probability of targeting truly pre-stellar phase, in order to uncover the genuine *initial* mass distribution. We design the observations with a careful strategy to ensure a robust cross comparison between the sources. The proposed study represents a major step forward in our understanding of the mass assembly process at the very beginning of cluster formation.
